sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Prior to initiating therapy, obtain baseline hepatic laboratory tests; repeat tests during the first 4 weeks of treatment and as clinically indicated thereafter.
  • Ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir/dasabuvir is indicated with or without ribavirin for the treatment of genotype 1 chronic hepatitis C virus, including patients with compensated cirrhosis.
  • Safety and efficacy not established in patients with hepatitis C virus genotypes other than genotype 1
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - Transplantation of liver, Normal hepatic function and mild fibrosis (Metavir fibrosis score, 2 or less): 2 tablets (ombitasvir 12.5 mg/paritaprevir 75 mg/ritonavir 50 mg) ORALLY once every morning plus 1 tablet (dasabuvir 250 mg) ORALLY twice daily in the morning and evening plus weight-based ribavirin (total daily dose: 1000 mg if less than 75 kg OR 1200 mg if 75 kg or more) administered in 2 divided doses twice daily with food; continue treatment for 24 weeks
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a with cirrhosis: 2 tablets (ombitasvir 12.5 mg/paritaprevir 75 mg/ritonavir 50 mg) ORALLY once every morning plus 1 tablet (dasabuvir 250 mg) ORALLY twice daily in the morning and evening plus weight-based ribavirin (total daily dose: 1000 mg if less than 75 kg OR 1200 mg if 75 kg or more) administered in 2 divided doses twice daily with food; continue treatment for 24 weeks.
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a without cirrhosis: 2 tablets (ombitasvir 12.5 mg/paritaprevir 75 mg/ritonavir 50 mg) ORALLY once every morning plus 1 tablet (dasabuvir 250 mg) ORALLY twice daily in the morning and evening plus weight-based ribavirin (total daily dose: 1000 mg if less than 75 kg OR 1200 mg if 75 kg or more) administered in 2 divided doses twice daily with food; continue treatment for 12 weeks.
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1b with cirrhosis: 2 tablets (ombitasvir 12.5 mg/paritaprevir 75 mg/ritonavir 50 mg) ORALLY once every morning plus 1 tablet (dasabuvir 250 mg) ORALLY twice daily in the morning and evening plus weight-based ribavirin (total daily dose: 1000 mg if less than 75 kg OR 1200 mg if 75 kg or more) administered in 2 divided doses twice daily with food; continue treatment for 12 weeks.
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1b without cirrhosis: 2 tablets (ombitasvir 12.5 mg/paritaprevir 75 mg/ritonavir 50 mg) ORALLY once every morning plus 1 tablet (dasabuvir 250 mg) ORALLY twice daily in the morning and evening; continue treatment for 12 weeks.

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Geriatrics: No adjustment required
  • Hepatic impairment, mild (Child-Pugh A): No adjustment required
  • Hepatic impairment, moderate (Child-Pugh B): Use not recommended
  • Hepatic impairment, severe (Child-Pugh C): Contraindicated
  • Renal impairment, any degree: No adjustment required

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - Transplantation of liver, Normal hepatic function and mild fibrosis (Metavir fibrosis score, 2 or less)
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a with cirrhosis
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a without cirrhosis
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1b with cirrhosis
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1b without cirrhosis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Coadministration with medications highly dependent on CYP3A for clearance and for which elevated concentrations may result in serious or life-threatening events (eg, alfuzosin, efavirenz, ergotamine, ergonovine, dihydroergotamine, methylergonovine, pimozide, sildenafil when used to treat pulmonary hypertension, simvastatin, lovastatin, triazolam, oral midazolam)
  • Coadministration with strong CYP3A and CYP2C8 inducers (eg, carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin, rifampin, St. John's wort)
  • Coadministration with strong CYP2C8 inhibitors (eg gemfibrozil)
  • Coadministration with ethinyl estradiol-containing medications, such as combined oral contraceptives
  • Hypersensitivity to ritonavir
  • Severe hepatic impairment

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Hepatic:
  • -- ALT elevations to greater than 5 times ULN have been reported; monitoring recommended; discontinuation may be necessary
  • Immunologic:
  • -- HCV/HIV-1 coinfection; HIV-1 protease inhibitor resistance-associated substitutions have been reported; administer a suppressive antiretroviral drug regimen
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- Voriconazole; use not recommended unless the benefit outweighs the potential risk
  • -- Darunavir/ritonavir, lopinavir/ritonavir, rilpivirine, salmeterol; use not recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (Without ribavirin, 7%; in combination with ribavirin, 10% to 24%), Pruritus (Without ribavirin; 7%; in combination with ribavirin, 13% to 18%; HCV/HIV-1 coinfection in combination with ribavirin, 13%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (Monotherapy, 8%; in combination with ribavirin, 16% to 22%; HCV/HIV-1 coinfection in combination with ribavirin, 17%; liver transplant in combination with ribavirin, 24%)
  • Neurologic:Insomnia (Without ribavirin, 5%; In combination with ribavirin, 12% to 14%; HCV/HIV-1 coinfection in combination with ribavirin, 19%; liver transplant in combination with ribavirin, 26%)
  • Other:Fatigue (In combination with ribavirin, 34%; HCV/HIV-1 coinfection in combination with ribavirin, 48%; liver transplant in combination with ribavirin, 50%)
Serious
Hepatic:ALT/SGPT level raised, greater than 5 times ULN (1%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: This medication is a combination of 3 direct-acting hepatitis C virus (HCV) antiviral agents (ombitasvir, paritaprevir, and dasabuvir) with ritonavir used to boost exposure of paritaprevir. Specifically, ombitasvir is an HCV NS5A inhibitor, paritaprevir is an HCV NS3/4A protease inhibitor, and dasabuvir is an HCV non-nucleoside NS5B palm polymerase inhibitor. These 3 agents target HCV at multiple steps in the viral lifecycle and have nonoverlapping resistance profiles. Ritonavir is a CYP3A inhibitor and does not have activity against HCV.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, oral, ombitasvir, paritaprevir, ritonavir and dasabuvir: 4 to 5 hours
  • Bioavailability, dasabuvir, oral: 70%; not established for ombitasvir, paritaprevir, and ritonavir
  • Effects of food; ombitasvir, paritaprevir, ritonavir, and dasabuvir: Increased exposure

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Protein binding, ombitasvir: 99.9%
  • Protein binding, paritaprevir: 97% to 98.6%
  • Protein binding, ritonavir: greater than 99%
  • Protein binding, dasabuvir: greater than 99.5%
  • Vd, ombitasvir: 50.1 L
  • Vd, paritaprevir: 16.7 L
  • Vd, ritonavir: 21.5 L
  • Vd, dasabuvir: 396 L

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Ombitasvir: Various locations
  • Paritaprevir: Hepatic
  • Ritonavir: Hepatic
  • Dasabuvir: Hepatic
  • Inhibitors of CYP3A4, UGT1A1, BCRP, OATP1B1, and OATP1B3
  • Substrates of CYP3A, CYP2C8, P-gp, BCRP, OATP1B1, and OATP1B3

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal excretion, ombitasvir: 1.91%, 0.03% unchanged
  • Renal excretion, paritaprevir: 8.8%, 0.05% unchanged
  • Renal excretion, ritonavir: 11.3%
  • Renal excretion, dasabuvir: 2%, 0.03% unchanged
  • Fecal, ombitasvir: 90.2%, 87.8% unchanged
  • Fecal, paritaprevir: 88%, 1.1% unchanged
  • Fecal, ritonavir: 86.4%
  • Fecal, dasabuvir: 94.4%, 26% unchanged

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• Ombitasvir: 21 to 25 hours
  • Paritaprevir: 5.5 hours
  • Ritonavir: 4 hours
  • Dasabuvir: 5.5 to 6 hours

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
Administer with a meal, without regard to fat or calorie count

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Determine hepatitis C genotype prior to initiation of therapy
  • Reduction from baseline in hepatitis C virus-RNA viral load may indicate efficacy
  • Hepatic labs; prior to treatment, first 4 weeks of treatment, and as clinically indicated thereafter

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Viekira Pak
KIT: (Dasabuvir;Ombitasvir - Paritaprevir - RitonavirDasabuvir;Ombitasvir - Paritaprevir - Ritonavir) 250 MG,12.5 MG,75 MG,50 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
AIDS ANTIVIRAL PROTEASE INHIBITORS
USES: Protease inhibitors are used in the treatment of HIV-1 infection. This class includes: atazanavir, darunavir, fosamprenavir calcium, indinavir sulfate, lopinavir/ritonavir, nelfinavir mesylate, ritonavir, saquinavir mesylate, and tipranavir. PHARMACOLOGY: Protease inhibitors reversibly bind the HIV-1 protease necessary for protein cleavage and subsequent enzyme (reverse transcriptase, protease, and integrase) activation leading to inhibition of infectivity. TOXICOLOGY: Toxicological effects are generally an extension of adverse effects. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is uncommon and severe sequelae from acute overdose are rare. However, adverse effects and drug interactions are common. OVERDOSE: There are limited overdose data, despite more than 15 years of availability. In general, overdose effects seem to be well tolerated. The following effects have been reported: INDINAVIR: nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, hematuria, crystalluria, renal insufficiency, and nephrolithiasis. RITONAVIR: vomiting, headache, and rash. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, peripheral neuropathy, and elevated liver enzymes are common. SEVERE: Severe effects include pancreatitis, liver failure, myelosuppression, heart block, and lactic acidosis. Other adverse effects specific to each drug include: ATAZANAVIR: hyperglycemia, hyperbilirubinemia (5%), nephrolithiasis, rash, nausea, vomiting, transaminitis, neutropenia (4%), hepatitis. DARUNAVIR: nausea, vomiting, lipodystrophy, transaminitis, hyperglycemia, rash, Stevens-Johnson syndrome (rare), hepatic failure (rare). FOSAMPRENAVIR: Transaminitis, hepatotoxicity (6%). INDINAVIR: Transaminitis, rash, nephrolithiasis (5%), hepatic steatosis (3%), lipodystrophy, and rarely, vasculitis, lactic acidosis, and rhabdomyolysis. LOPINAVIR/RITONAVIR: hepatotoxicity, rash, hypercholesterolemia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea. NELFINAVIR: transaminitis, hepatotoxicity (5%). RITONAVIR: nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, paresthesias, hypercholesterolemia, hepatotoxicity, and rash, all of which are largely dose-dependent. SAQUINAVIR: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain are common. TIPRANAVIR: Transaminitis, hepatotoxicity (10%), rash, nausea, vomiting. DRUG INTERACTIONS: Drug interactions are common with this class of medications; most are mediated by Cytochrome P450 3A4. Drugs that are 3A4 inhibitors will decrease the metabolism of most protease inhibitors and increase toxicity. Administration of most protease inhibitors with drugs that are 3A4 substrates decreases metabolism and increases toxicity of these other drugs. Fosamprenavir, nelfinavir, ritonavir, saquinavir, atazanavir, and darunavir are all P450 3A4 substrates and inhibitors. Tipranavir, lopinavir/ritonavir, and indinavir are P450 3A4 substrates only.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
AIDS ANTIVIRAL PROTEASE INHIBITORS
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Supportive care remains the mainstay of care. Mild transaminitis can be monitored; discontinuation of therapy is usually not necessary. Therapy should be changed for persistently rising transaminases or evidence of hepatic synthetic dysfunction. Nausea and vomiting should be treated with antiemetics. Peripheral neuropathies are generally reversible with drug withdrawal and can be treated with pain management as needed. Mild elevations in lactic acid do not require discontinuation of therapy unless systemic acidemia ensues. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Supportive care remains the mainstay of care in severe toxicity. Withdrawal of the offending agent is imperative to improvement in severe adverse reactions. Stevens-Johnson Syndrome should be treated with supportive care and consideration of corticosteroid and IV immunoglobulin therapy. Granulocyte colony stimulating factor (GCSF) should be considered for neutropenia complicated by infection felt to be secondary to protease inhibitors. Hepatic failure should prompt consultation with a transplant center.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: No prehospital decontamination is indicated. Prehospital care should focus on assessment of vital signs and general supportive care. HOSPITAL: Activated charcoal may be considered for patients who present early after overdose if they are awake and willing to drink the charcoal. Gastric lavage is not indicated as overdose is not life-threatening.
  • Antidote: None
  • Monitoring of patient: Obtain a basic metabolic panel, and monitor CBC and liver enzymes in symptomatic patients. Right upper quadrant ultrasound should be considered to evaluate for alternative etiologies of transaminitis.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis and whole bowel irrigation have no role in the management of protease inhibitor overdose.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Suicidal patients should be referred to a healthcare facility. Asymptomatic patients with inadvertent ingestion of a protease inhibitor can be observed at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic patients should be observed for 4 to 6 hours, primarily monitoring signs of co-ingestant toxicity. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients with severe toxicity should be admitted. Patients with hepatic failure or severe acidosis should be admitted to an intensive care setting. CONSULT CRITERIA: Infectious disease should be consulted if a change to anti-retroviral therapy is indicated. Consult a medical toxicologist or poison center for patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is unclear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
AIDS ANTIVIRAL PROTEASE INHIBITORS
TOXICITY: INDINAVIR: 52 out of 79 adults developed moderate toxicity after ingesting 2.8 to 48 g; most recovered rapidly. LOPINAVIR/RITONAVIR: An adult developed vomiting, abdominal pain and headache after ingesting 54 g lopinavir and 13.5 g ritonavir as combination therapy; he recovered. RITONAVIR: An adult, who ingested 1500 mg/day for 2 days, developed paresthesias which resolved with dose reduction. SAQUINAVIR: An ingestion of 8 g caused no toxicity, and 7200 mg/day for 25 weeks was well tolerated. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies by specific agent.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn female patients of childbearing potential to avoid becoming pregnant during treatment. Contact a healthcare professional immediately if pregnancy occurs.
  • Inform patient that alternative methods of contraception are recommended during treatment (ie, progestin only or nonhormonal methods) and for at least 2 weeks following discontinuation. Ethinyl estradiol-containing methods may be restarted after 2 weeks.
  • Tell patient to take appropriate precautions to prevent transmission of hepatitis C infection as effect of drug on transmission is unknown.
  • Side effects may include itching, skin reactions, insomnia, or asthenia.
  • Advise patient to immediately report symptoms of liver inflammation (ie, fatigue, weakness, lack of appetite, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, or discoloration of feces).
  • Instruct patient to take drug with food.
  • Advise patient there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult healthcare professional before new drug use (including over-the counter and herbal drugs).
  • Tell patient that a missed dose of ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir may be taken within 12 hours. A missed dose of dasabuvir may be taken within 6 hours. If more time has passed, skip the missed dose.
